```{python}
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

sns.set(style="whitegrid")

# Before data (all 0s)
data = {
    "Book": ["Old Testament", "New Testament", "Book of Mormon", "Pearl of Great Price", "D & C"],
    "Verses Read": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0],
    "Chapters Read": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df_melted = df.melt(id_vars="Book", var_name="Reading Type", value_name="Count")

# Create the bar plot
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 7))
ax = sns.barplot(
    data=df_melted,
    x="Count",
    y="Book",
    hue="Reading Type",
    palette="Set2"
)

# Set larger fonts for clarity
plt.title("Daily Scripture Reading Over 27 Days", fontsize=22, fontweight='bold')
plt.xlabel("Reading Activity Level", fontsize=18)
plt.ylabel("Scripture Book", fontsize=18)

# Increase tick label size
ax.tick_params(axis='x', labelsize=16)
ax.tick_params(axis='y', labelsize=16)

# Slightly larger legend text
plt.legend(title="Reading Type", title_fontsize=17, fontsize=15)

# Add value labels to real bars only
for p in ax.patches:
    value = int(p.get_width())
    height = p.get_height()

    # Only label real visible bars (width 0 is still valid for labeling 0, but height must exist)
    if height > 0 and p.get_y() is not None:
        if value > 0:
            ax.text(p.get_width() + 1,
                    p.get_y() + height / 2,
                    str(value),
                    va='center', fontsize=13)
        else:
            # Show a '0' label slightly offset
            ax.text(1,  # Place slightly into bar area
                    p.get_y() + height / 2,
                    '0',
                    va='center', fontsize=13, color='gray')

# Set x-axis limit for better layout (optional: adjust as needed)
plt.xlim(0, 200)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

# AFTER CHART WITH LABELS
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set style
sns.set(style="whitegrid")

# After data
data = {
    "Book": ["Old Testament", "New Testament", "Book of Mormon", "Pearl of Great Price", "D & C"],
    "Verses Read": [75, 38, 150, 72, 15],
    "Chapters Read": [3, 2, 6, 4, 1]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df_melted = df.melt(id_vars="Book", var_name="Reading Type", value_name="Count")

# Create the bar plot
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 7))
ax = sns.barplot(
    data=df_melted,
    x="Count",
    y="Book",
    hue="Reading Type",
    palette="Set2"
)

# Set larger fonts for clarity
plt.title("Daily Scripture Reading Over 27 Days", fontsize=22, fontweight='bold')
plt.xlabel("Reading Activity Level", fontsize=18)
plt.ylabel("Scripture Book", fontsize=18)

# Increase tick label size
ax.tick_params(axis='x', labelsize=16)
ax.tick_params(axis='y', labelsize=16)

# Slightly larger legend text
plt.legend(title="Reading Type", title_fontsize=17, fontsize=15)

# Add value labels only for values > 0
for p in ax.patches:
    value = int(p.get_width())
    if value > 0:
        ax.text(p.get_width() + 1,
                p.get_y() + p.get_height() / 2,
                str(value),
                va='center', fontsize=18)

# Set x-axis limit for better layout (optional: adjust as needed)
plt.xlim(0, 200)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
